newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia may have election next year - Costello.
newsitem.headline: Australia may have election next year - Costello.

text.p: Australian Treasurer Peter Costello said on Tuesday the country could have a national election in 1998.
"There could well be another federal election next year," he said in a speech at a business lunch.
The conservative Liberal-National government was elected for its first three-year term in March, 1996. The next election would ordinarily be due in early 1999.
Costello later told reporters that the government's three-year term would be up by the end of 1998, but he was also unsure what impact parliament's upper house, the senate, would have.

"I think that (1998) would be the natural timing, and of course we do not know how the senate is going to play out," he said. "I hope the Senate does co-operate over the course of this year and next."
The government can dissolve both houses of parliament and call an early election if the senate twice blocks government legislation.

The government faces senate obstruction over at least two key reforms -- a planned solution to a land rights row between farmers and Aborigines and proposed labour reforms that would make it easier for small business to sack new workers.
The constitution is vague about election timing.
The House of Representatives officially expires three years after its first sitting -- which take it to April, 1999.
But the election can be held several months earlier or later under a range of circumstances.
Costello also said he supported four-year parliamentary terms instead of three years.
"I think we do need four-year federal terms ... the parliamentary terms are so short these days that it does restrict many of your options," he said.
